string.text: Galend overlooks the wave-beaten Biscan coast. It takes in the catch from the Biscan's intrepid fishermen who venture out far into the western ocean, as well as the wool of sheep from the green fog-covered hills. The current line of Vlandian kings comes from the clans who settled in this region during Osric Iron-Arm's invasion.

Ortongard sits in the dry center of the Devseg plateau, which is dry for most of the year but offers rich grazing in the spring. Founded by Darshi-speaking merchants, it made its wealth buying horses, sheep and cattle from the surrounding herding villages and sending them west to the markets of the empire in huge drives, accompanied by guards to ward off raiders from the steppes. Neither its walls nor its mercenary armies could withstand the coming of Khan Urkhun, however, who it granted to the Khergit clan in recognition of their valor.
Varagos sits on the Aris river, a small highland stream that flows into the deep pool known as the Ophthys. The land here is not especially rich, but is sufficient for the raising of sheep.

Ataconia sits on a plateau in the piedmont of the Dryatic mountains. The streams rushing down from the mountains have exposed deposits of salt in the hillsides, which are mined by the local population.

Hertogea lies in the shadow of Mount Erithrys, a huge basalt slab thrust up from the depths of the earth. Villagers grow olives on the slopes leading up the mountain, famous for their light, fragrant oil.

Oristocorys sits on the Bay of Ortysia, part of the seaway between the western ocean and the Perassic Sea. Early morning sea-mists from the west and the hot sun of midday allow the growing of wine grapes.
Elvania sits on the Bay of Ortysia, part of the seaway between the western ocean and the Perassic Sea. Olive trees grow on the slopes of the nearby hills, warmed by the southern sun.
The village of Esme and its surrounding hamlets lie on the landward side of the Akkan hills on the Devseg plateau, prime grazing lands for the flocks of the Khuzaits and their confederates.

Khimli sits in a basin the Devseg plateau. Though this land is dry most of the year, it experiences winter snowfalls and muddy springs. Fine clay can be collected from the pools left by the snowmelt and the rains.

Karahalli lies in the far north of the Khuzait confederacy, in borderlands contested by the Sturgians. Though the winters are cold, the spring grasses are fine grazing for the local sheep, whose thick wool protects them from the region's piercing winds.
Erzenur alongside the Tiagys river, known in the local dialect as the Teyagh. The waters here have a distinct reddish tint from the iron in the soil, which the villagers mine from riverside outcrops.
Hongard sits in the warm wooded lands near the meandering Trand river. This land, rich in wheat and once the heartland of the Empire, is now the center of the Vlandian kingdom.
Drapand sits near the tip of Cape Fal, a promontory just south of the mouth of the Trand River. The villagers venture out far into the seas to cod-rich banks washed by a cold current from the north.

Ormanfard sits by a small, fast-flowing river that runs down from the mountains of the Rhennod to fill the lake known as Ocspool. The hillsides here are terraced for the growing of grapes, which produce a heavy, rich vintage that the wealthy drink mixed with honey and cloves, and the common folk with water.

Sirindac lies beneath the high ridges of the Ebor peninsula, somewhat sheltered from the bitter winds blowing out of the northwest. Villagers here dig a fine pale clay, rich in mica and feldspar, from the mountain streams.
Talivel in the middle of the Trand valley in the heartland of Calradia. Villagers plant olives here on the hillsides.
Tor Melina sits in a marshy basin in the dark forested hills of the northwestern Uchalion massif. Villagers take clay from the damp soil for sale to the potters of nearby towns.

Marathea lies on a narrow shelf of land between the Miron river and Mount Aracathos, the tallest peak in the Dryatic mountains. The villagers are skilled miners, extracting iron ores from the nearby cliffside.
Avalyps sits near the headwaters of the River Calsa in the warm coastal hills of the southern Empire.The dark, well-watered soil here makes this region an imperial breadbasket.
Zestea sits where the plains of Lycarea meet the coastal Iltaric hills. Swine forage for acorns in the oak groves overlooking the hazy flatlands.

Montos sits at the base of the Cursion escarpment, near the Battanian frontier. The foresters here keep a watchful eye on their neighbors, always looking for raiding parties coming westward from the valley of the Miron river to their east.

Gamardan sits at the head of a small bay that branches off the larger Gulf of Charas. Tuna gather to spawn just offshore, and the fishermen of the area corral the large fish with nets before hauling them on board with grappling hooks.

Vinela sits beneath the waterfalls where the Aminys river rushes down to join the Perassic Sea. Fishing boats set out each day from beneath the coastal cliffs, harvesting mackerel, sardines and bonito from the rich waters where the river meets the sea.
Carphenion lies in the wooded highlands between the great basalt slab of Mount Erithrys and the Dryatic mountains. The villagers raise cattle in the highland pastures.
Hanekhy sits atop a northern spur of the Akkan hills. The reddish streaks in the soil and rocks testify to rich iron deposits, which are mined by the villagers.
Omrotok sits at the foot of the Sulun Dag mountains, that mark the eastern border of the Devseg plateau. Villagers go to the nearby woods to harvest one of the Devseg's few sources of timber.
Ransam in the southeastern plains of the Devseg plateau. Villagers, who not long ago still lived a nomadic lifestyle, specialize in the rearing of horses.
Urunjan near the western edge of the Devseg plateau, at the foot of the Akkan hills. Villagers raise cattle here that are bred to withstand both the hot summers and freezing winters.

Kargrev was once Car Gryff, the ringfort of the Battanian chief Gryff, but was conquered by the Sturgians two generations ago. It lies alongside the Bay of Varcheg, where the local fishermen take advantage of the relatively sheltered waters of the bay, where fish of many kinds come to spawn.

The villagers of Kvol raise small, sturdy cattle at the base of the Chertyg mountains. They include the descendants of refugees and malcontents from across Calradia, seeking isolation in the cold northern forests.
Korsyas sits near the narrowest part of the Bay of Varcheg. Villagers fish the waters to the west for cod, char, and other cold-water sea fish that venture into the bay.
Calioc on a flat plain between the Epiric and Biscan hills of the central Vlandian lands. The people of this district grow flax on the marshy lands.

Meroc is a fishing village overlooking a cove in the Biscan Coast. The villagers sail out into the western ocean in search of mullet and bass near the shore, and tuna and sardines amid the islands to the south.
Nogrent sits on a slope of the Biscan hills in central Vlandia. Villagers here raise sheep on the pastures between the coastal woods and the high crags of the hills.
Arromanc lies in the Neurval, a valley that runs between the Biscan and Epiric hills. The warm lands of the Vlandian south are well-suited to the growing of olives.
Mot lies in the Neurval, a valley that runs between the Biscan and Epiric hills. The warm lands of the Vlandian south are well-suited to the growing of olives.
Chornad sits overlooking a pass through the Biscan hills. The villagers of this region, like many in the central Vlandian kingdom, specializing in the raising of pigs.
